This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.

div.head: Cyprus Government Railway.
div.p: The Limassol S.S. Co. steamers with good passenger accommodation run between Cyprus & Egypt as follows:—

Trains run alongside the steamers on the quay, and passengers can be conveyed to Famagusta, Nicosia, Morphou and intermediate stations. Good hotel accommodation for tourists is provided at Famagusta, at the Savoy Hotel (Mr. Najem Houry proprietor). Olympus Hotel, Mount Troodos, 6000 ft. above the sea. Magnificent Scenery. Perfect climate. Season May to end of October. For information apply to Mr. Najem Houry, Managing Director of Cyprus Hotel Co., Army Contractor, Limassol, Cyprus. There is a good carriage road from Kopia (on Railway) to Troodos. At Famagusta may be seen the fine old Latin Cathedral (now a mosque) begun in 1300 and finished in 1312, together with other ancient ruins and the Venetian fortifications, the finest in the world. Also the tower or palace, the scene of “Othello'' and of Ford's “Lover's Melancholy.'' The climate of Cyprus in the winter months is delightful and the Island will well repay a visit.
Information as to tickets, trains, etc., may be obtained of Messrs. Thomas Cook & Son, Egypt, or from the General Manager Railways, Famagusta. G. BERT DAY, General Manager. 29248—31-12-907

div.head: LOCAL AND GENERAL
div.p: >An Egyptian Army band will benceforward play at she Gizech Zoological Gardens on Sunday afternoon and the Gizeh boys band on Friday afternoons. Three giraffes of the Zoo have been moved to a large new paddock, 155 metres in circummference

The expenses of the Mahmal Guard for this year has been fixed to be I.E 8,565, sgaitat I.E. 3,009 Yor last year. The guard will be composed of half of the 4th Battalion under the command of a field officer, who is to be selected by the War Office.

Water will be supplied at first in Khartoum only for the purpose of sprinkling the streets and watering the trees and public gardens. The water will not be distributed for use by the residents until it has undergone a through chemical analysis, so as to ascertain its fitness for drinking purposes.

A petition is being signed by a number of landowners at Ikingui-Mariout, addressed to De Martine Pasha, Director of the Daira Khassa. The petitioners beg that a service of trains should be run between Alexandris and that station and that all trains on the Khedivial line should stop there both going and coming.

Messrs Thos. Cook and Sons vew paddle steamer the ,“Egypt” was open to the inspection of the pubhe yesterday afternoon, and general admiration was expressed at her appearance and fittings. A band was in attendance apd played during the afternoon, and tea was served on the upper deck, which was crowded with visitors.

Yesterday afternoon Mr. Sergyos Qetotch-kine’s elie balloon, of a capacity of 600 cubic metres when inflated, made an ascent at 426 p.m. from Rond-Point At 6 o'clock the balloon descended on the left bank of the Mahmoudieh canal in a field under cultiation. The occupants were assaulted violently, on reaching the earth, by irate natives who had to be driven away by the police.

The troupe now engaged by the Tour Eiffel management at Alexandria is meeting with great success Mime Valentino has gained much popularity by ber chatacteristic songs, which she renders in the true Parisian style, and the acrobatic feats of the Dao Dermotta are an especial attraction. Mile Manolita is now giving a new dance, the Japanese Doll, and on Wednesday we are to see the debut of the Dharvier troupe.
The two fire engines ordered for Omdarman arrived last week. One of them is a team

engine of the style known as “Merryweather's Valiant”. The other is workéd by hand, Mr Southgate, Superintendant of Police, Khartoum Province, has put them up, and they are now almost ready for use. A steam fire-engine, similar to the one recently brought to Omdurman, has been ordered for Khartouth. It will not be put into use, however, until the water-works are in full operation. This we understand, will be about one month hence.

The world-renowned Fregoli is at the Abbas Theatre in Cairo and we would recommend all those who bave not already see him to lose no time in doing so, and those who have been once will need no further inducement to repeat their visit, than they possess in the knowledge of the excellence of the entertainment, for if ever one man has held an audience spell bound for an entire evening Fregoli certainly did so last night, when for,the second time he appeared before the crowded house in the hundred and one characters whom he impersonates so well. It is impossible to choose any one character as being more perfectly played than another, for M. Pregoli is an artist to his finger tips, and the queraloas toves of the voluble elderly lady come as naturally to him as does the deep gromble of an itrate householder disturbed in his slambers by an imaginary burglar. Much of the success of the evening was also due to the manrer in which the orchestra acquitted themselves of the difficult task of following M: Bregoli through his ever changing moods, the accompaniment being almost buman in the various displays of the pleasure, dismay and anger which if was called upon to represent.

div.head: COUNCIL OF MINISTERS
div.p: At the Council of Miristers which was held under the presidency of the Khedive at the Abdin Palace on Saturday morning of the following decrees were approved--
The apporntment of Mr. Edward Bateson, Barrister at Law, London, appointed as Judge of the Native Tribunal at Keneh.
The appointment of Mobammed Tewfik Nessim Effendi, as 2nd Class Judge, at the Native Tribunal of the Ist Class Cairo
The substitution of a new plan of allotment of the Wakfs El Abmadi at Tantah.
The creation of two new cemetries in the Provinces of Menoufieh and Beni Suef.

div.head: WINDSOR HOTEL.
div.p: Facing the Sea on the New Quay of Alexandria
FIRST CLASS HOTEL.
Lately Built and Furnished.
TERMS P.T.50 PER DAY.

div.head: A SUDANESE SULTAN
div.p: TOMBORA AT KHARTOUM

The Sultan Tombora, of the Bahr el-Ghazal, who is on a visit to Khartoum was received by the Govenor-General on Friday week. He expressed his gratitude, for the kind treatment with which he has been treated, and for the numerous presents which have been bestowed upon him and his followers. He gave assurance of his loyalty to the Government and his readiness to comply with its instructions, and to rule his people in accordance with its regulations.

On Saturday week a dinner was given at the Omdurman Zabtieh in honour of Sultan Tombora and the other Sultans visiting Omdurman. Tombora was much pleased with the phonograph which supplied the music for the occasion

Sultan Tombora and his retinue, consisting of his son, his brother, his wives and about a dozen servants left Omdurman yesterday week returning to his country. He goes back carrying with him pleasant recollections of his short visit to these parts. He has evidently been very favourably impressed with what he witnessed here, and has expressed his desire to send four of his sons to Khartoam to be educated at Gordon College.
The “Sudan Times” says —
The Sultan's a very genial person. He speaks Arabic fairly well. Asked about his age he was not able to give a reply ; the Niams Niams

do not seem to have a regular way of measuring time. But by bis looks one can judge that he is between fifty and sixty years old He states that when Zabeir Pasha was a young boy, and has no clear recollection of him.

Tombora has a large number of wives, exact number of whom he does not know ; nor does he seem to know the exact number of his children. But they are not less than fifty, a number of whom are already established as sheiths of different districts within his dominions. His successors as Sulton, will not be his oldest son, but one of his younger children whom he has designated an account of being more intelligent than the others, and hence more promising.

He says that the Niam Niams are no longer cannibals. Cannibalism was practiced by them in the past but on very rare ocassions. The people of a tribe never at the flesh of their own tribesmen. But when a man got old or helplessly sick, he was made a present of to another tribe which would feed upon his flesh, returning the favour to the former tribe when they had a similar opportunity.

div.head: INTRRNATIONAL HYGIENE, BUREAC.
div.p: London, Monday.

Dr. Ruffer has been appointed member of the committee for drafting regulations for the establishment in Paris of an international hygiene boreau. Great Britain and India are each entitled to six votes and Ibrahim Pasha states that Egypt is entitled to three votes.

div.head: NEW MACHINE GUN
div.p: (Gazette's Special Service)
Londonv, Monday.

Great interest has heen aroused in military circles by the extraordinary new machine gun invented by Major Fitzgerald, the Crimean veteran. The gun can be mounted anywhere under five minutes and has a range of 3.400 yards

div.head: THE KHEDIVE
div.p: The Khedive gave audience on Satarday morning to Si-Kbalil Bouhagib, husband of Princess Nazlé Hanem, who presented to the Khedive Si-Beshir Safar, Director of Wakfs at Tunis; Sir Eldon Gorst, who presented: the Rev. Molesworth ; Count Lavison ; Mohammed Tewfik Rifaat Bey, new Concillor of the native Court ot Appeal, who took the oath before his Highness prior fo assuming his functions and Mohammed Khelil Pasha, who tendered thanks for his promotion to the rank of Mirmiran. The Khedive arrived Inst nigh at Alexandria.

div.head: PORTS AND LIGHTS.
div.p: TRIAL OP THE OFFICIALS.

The Native Criminal Court presented an unusually animated appearance this morning, when Judge Mohamed Bey Said took his seat on the bench to preside at the trial of the officials of the Ports and Lights Administration accused of bribery and corruption. The name of the late Secretary General of the Administration, Socrates Spiro Bey, was called out in Court, but this person, who is one of the accused, failed to put in an appearance, preferring to remain in Europe. The next ex-official of the Administration called was Attiah Effendi George, who is accused, together with Spiro Bey, of having received a bribe of £54 from Hafez Gobran in order to promote him to the post of chief storekeeper in the Administration. Attiah Effendi George was present. The first witness calledbnwas Hafez Gobran, who stated that he.did not wish to be appointed a clerk as Spiro and George suggested he should be. He asked to be promoted to chief storekeeper, so the two officials asked him for £100 to carry it through Finally he offered to pay £6". He paid first £20 to George and agreed to’pay the balance afterwards. The Court is still sitting as we go to press.

div.head: CAIRO OPERA SEASON
div.p: HERODIADE

It is certainly a comfort after the ungainly fiasooes of last year to hear an opera decently performed, without obvious failures in orchestra, chorus and soloists. M. Poncet has evidently, though it is early in the season to judge, made a far more careful and judicious selection. As to the opera itself, Herodiade is hardly a piece for any but the baritones: the others have their chance, but it ts hardly a “obeval de bataille” for them. Perhaps the reason lies in the music. One cannot help feeling that Massenet was not in his element ; he was hungering, perhaps unconsciously after the light timeful satirical ‘genre,’ so apparent in his “Gongleur™ or “Cendrillon,” oppressed, it may be by the solemnity and even andacity of his subject. For a moment he rises to it, in the enrty of the priests, but then again the voluptuous, unsatisfied theme intrudes. As to the performance, the chorus were sound all through, as was the orchestra, though a trifle bald in parts. The prophet’s entry was marred by overmuch noise in the wind instruments, and now and again in the chorus the altos tended to overshadow the sopranos, and produce a slightly crude effect. M. Soubeyran had as suggested, hardly that chance which should enable him to show the best of his voice, but in the dungeon scene (or it should be grotto) he rose to distinct excellence. His artticulation is notably good and clear, but occasionally his attack seems to hesitate. Mile Magne as Salome was admirable for technique, but also rather colourless : her voice sounded constrained at moments. Mr. Vallette as Herod rose to the part ; his fine resonant voice suited the part and the sentiment of the mosic, and he introduced shades and tones of passion and longing with real effect ; whether he will do as well in other parts remains to be seen. Mr. Loiglio was distinctly good as Phannel; he also has as fine voice, full, deep, and true. On the whole it was a very even, creditable performance, without any of the glaring massacres of downright bad singing that spoilt last years opera. The rest of the repertoire which is varied and interesting will doubtless show what the company can or cannot do. We may at least hope that it will be a distinct improvement.

div.head: THE REORGANIZATION OF THE CADRE
div.p: The Council of Ministers, at its meeting on Saturday, approved, on the proposal of the Minister of Finance the following arrangements regarding the reoranization of cadre.

1.—The credit of L.E. 72,000 inscribed on the budget of 1907 for the reorganisation of the cadre is divided among the State Adninistrations to serve to ameliorate the situation of the administrative and technical staff.
2.—The classes of the administrative cadre are fixed as follows :
4th class from L.E. 5 to 8
Assistant chef de bureau " " 24 to 28
Chef de Bureau " " 30 to 35
Assistant Director " " 37 to 43
Director " " 47 to 65

3.— By means of the sam allocated to it for its administrative staff to be drawn from the credit L.E. 72,000 each administration should first proceed to the claasification of its employees in the new cadre, the pay remaining over after this classification will serve the chief distribution for a better distribution of employments among the various classes of the cadre, according to the needs of service, in such manner as to increase the employments of the superior classes and to accord promotion on to the deserving employees.

4.—As regards the technical staff the chiefs of the Department will prepare the cadre which they judge best adapted to this staff within the limits of the portion of the credit of L.E. 72,000 at their disposal.
5.—The increases of salary and the promotions resulting from the present reorganization of the cadre will have a retroactive effect from 1st January 1907.

6.—The administrations at presnt regulated by the decrees of the 4the November 1893 and 24th June 1901 will alone benefit from the arrangements relative to the reorganization of the cadre. However, the staff whose condition bas been already ameliorated by previous decisions will not be admitted to the benefits derivable from the present arrangement.
7.—The number of working hours is at fixed at six in the Ministries and Administrations where it is already less than this figure.

div.head: STRAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The Mossi liner “Seti” sailed on Saturday afternoon last, for Liverpool via Malta with passengers, mails and general cargo, including 5, 135 bales of cotton.
The Canard S.S, “Cypria” arrived at Liverpool on Friday afternoon.
The S.S. "Cyprian Prince" with general cargo left Antwerp on the 6th inst., and is due to arrive at Alexandria on or about the 26th Deecember.

div.head: LETTER TO THE EDITOR
div.p: We do not hold ourselves responsible for the opinions expressed by our correspondents, but we wish, in a spirit of fait play to all, to permit---within certain necessary limits---free discussion.
COMPANIES IN EGYPT
TO THE EDITOR OF THE "EGYPTIAN GAZETTE."

Sir,—“Lex” has none too soon sounded the note of alarm as regards the anamalousposition of English companies in Egypr having alien boards It behoves, therefore, the shareholders in soi-disant English companies to be "up and doing." So far as we know, and English court has no power that the Mixed Tribanals have any such jurisdiction over the members of the board of an English company are free from any criminal responsibility. It is a notorious that, as a consequence of tis situation, many of these alien direrctors are simply the "dummies" of an individual or of a company having an axe to grind. Let me illustrate my meaning : According to English law, no director of a company can be directly or indirectly interested, pecuniarily or other wise, in any transaction supported by him as a member of the board. But, if he be an alien, he can, with inpunity, vote for the employment of the company's capital or reserves in the carrying out of schemes devised primarily for the profit of the wire-pullers whose interests he represents. Might I suggest that some clearer definition is necessary of the word "proprietor" in connection with the qualification shares of a director. The evident legal meaning of the word is that a director should have a real bona-fide interest in the company whose interests he controls. Is this always so, in fact
Yours truly,
VIGILANT
Alexandria, 7th December.
